Ray V wrote:
> I'm going through the process right now of adding test
> cases, but as I write them I'm constantly fighting the
> urge to fix stuff.  My question: is it better to write
> all the tests first, then go back to fixing what's
> broken, or to fix the bugs and "smelly" code as you go?

Michael Feather's "Working Effectively with Legacy Code" is what you want... :)

However, here's one recommendation: make the changes, so you can learn what 
the code does better. Then, _rollback_ your changes, so that you have the 
smelly code again. Write tests with your new understanding, and use these 
tests to both protect and guide you in your improvements. (Michael calls 
this technique "Scratch Refactoring")

Robert.
